话题：

If you've ever been disturbed by the noise of line dance, please share with us your experience.
Present your opinions towards these students' action and give some advice on this kind of dispute. 
 

范例1：

In fact, my grandma and even my dear mother have ever been the members of the line dance team in the community. They set out to go dancing on 7 o'clock and came back by 9 o'clock every evening. In their words, line dance is an interesting exercise which could improve their health condition. But as for me, they were just following the crowd, never considering its practical effect. I am not denying the positive functions of the line dance. The point I want to emphasize here is that not all people dance for good health and some just do it for fun. The noise problem caused by the line dance is not very serious in my city. In my opinion, the most fundamental reason for these disputes is that the public entertainment facilities the government invests to construct cannot meet the increasing physical fitness needs of middle-aged and elderly people. This can not be blamed entirely on some people's uncivilized behaviours or impolite words. Therefore, to decrease such disputes, the government should increase its investment in the construction of public entertainment facilities, and provide those dancers with an appropriate place. Meanwhile, the people themselves should also improve their own civilization quality and self-consciousness. Just as the saying goes, "Do not do to others what you would not have others do to you", and if those dancers can place themselves as one of those victims, they'll understand their annoyance. Only when both the people and the government take positive measures towards the line dance can the life be more beautiful and harmonious.
 
范例2：

That kind of dancing is not very popular inmy place. Usually some old people form as a small group and use a mini radio todance. The noise is not very loud and would not disturb the others. When I walkpass their place, I often like to see how they dance and how they enjoythemselves.

I think it is the matter of respect.Everyone has the rights to enjoy their life. We can do exercises, play games orsing songs only if the activities would not violate the rights of the others.Keeping the noise to an acceptable volume is a basic rule to hold on anyactivities. I could not find any excuses for them. So I hope all the dancerscan pay respect to the others. 


范例3：
I have no prejudice against the old people, and I think the line dance is a good way for them to entertain and socialize. But in China, good deeds sometimes can become a nuisance. This is the case. A bunch grandmas and grandpas gather in the little plaza or some open space in your neighborhood to dance, they really enjoy it. However, they really need to use the loudspeaker and have fun until night. The residents around have their own life and they do not appreciate the performance of the line dance. Thus the interest of conflict appears and when the residents cannot stand the noise and the bizarre activities, quarrels emerge. How should we solve this problem, actually, it’s quite easy. When we do something to entertain ourselves, we should consider the feeling of people around. In the case, the line dancers they should turn down their music, when night falls, they definitely should pack themselves and go back home, leaving the neighborhood quiet and peaceful. Then ,every one would have a nice dream, huh ?

description:
First today the World Bank has announced that it's suspending $90 million worth of aid for Uganda because of the country's decision to enact a tough new anti-homosexual law. The money was earmarked for Uganda's health service. But the bank says it wants to guarantee the projects the money was destined for are not going to be adversely affected by the new law. Ugandan government has accused the bank of blackmail. Jonathan Glennie is from Britain's Overseas Development Institute. I asked him what he makes of the bank's decision.

The western massive hypocrite's on this. We've supported horrific regimes in the past when it's in our own strategic interests. But yeah, and that's why we have to get to the main question - what is gonna be the impact of this? And there're two sides to it. Will actually international pressure using aid money persuade the Ugandan government to change its mind on this anti-gay law either in the short or medium term? And then the other side of that, what are gonna be the negative consequences of withdrawing aid, as if you said, this aid had nothing to do with, you know, human rights or gay rights, this aid was going to keeping people alive and health benefits for the kids, the mothers, etc, etc. Now I think that the international community should consider very deeply how it can use its force to encourage human rights. This is clearly a massive human rights violation, which I totally disagree with. Nevertheless, I'm not convinced that withdrawing aid is going to persuade the Ugandan government in the short term to or even in the medium term to actually change its mind on this.

SUMMARY：

百度挑战谷歌争夺新市场
 
CONTENT：
THERE is a gold rush going on at the digital frontier. As the economies of the likes of Brazil and India grow, so does the demand for web services of the kind that Westerners have come to take for granted: fast, reliable and ubiquitous.
We've heard a lot about established tech giants' plans to deliver internet to the masses. Facebook wants to use drones; Google is opting for high-flying balloons. Others are hard at work on websites specially designed for non-Western cultures. Now there is a new player in the game, and it may change the rules.
Baidu, a search engine based in Beijing, has lofty ambitions. Having conquered China, it is expanding into other growing digital markets, including Brazil, Egypt and Thailand. It is also busily setting up labs to perform the kind of cutting-edge research at which Google excels (see "The new Google? Baidu's big plans to bust out of China"). More and more, it seems, Baidu is not satisfied with simply emulating US companies at home: it wants to become the developing world's Google.
